entries.definition: Forefather of Israel; covenant bearer whose descendants form the Israelite people.
First man formed by YHWH from the ground (adamah), bearer of the divine image.
entries.usage_notes: Name roots (’adam/’adamah) evoke earth/soil tones; Scripture centers covenant vocation over appearance. Restoring dignity: humanity’s origin is earth-toned and honorable, not a basis for prejudice.

entries.definition: Pertaining to Adam; symbolic of earthy composition and melanated origin.

entries.etymology: Modern compound term describing ties between Africa (esp. Nile corridor) and the Levant.
entries.definition: Describes peoples, trade, or cultural links spanning Northeast Africa and the Levant in antiquity.
entries.usage_notes: Useful umbrella term; definitions vary by scholar and period.

entries.definition: Macedonian conqueror (356–323 BCE) whose empire spread Hellenism across the Near East; viewed in prophetic typology as the 'notable horn' of the Grecian goat.
entries.usage_notes: Though ethnically Macedonian, Alexander’s conquests furthered the Gentile dominion descending from Edomite-influenced Greece and Rome. His empire’s cultural legacy established the framework for later European imperial powers identified with the dragon and the beast.

entries.definition: Grandson of Esau through Eliphaz and Timna; progenitor of the Amalekites, Israel’s first national enemy.
entries.usage_notes: The Amalekites attacked Israel in the wilderness (Exodus 17:8–16), causing YHWH to declare perpetual war against them. Amalek embodies the enduring enmity of Edom’s seed toward Israel through successive empires.

entries.definition: Lineage from Esau via Eliphaz; archetypal adversary of Israel. Project stance: branch within Edomite continuum impacting later polities.
Nomadic foes of Israel from Amalek; opposed Israel from the Exodus onward.
Western continent shaped by European colonization; in prophetic interpretation, linked by some to Babylon the Great due to global reach and moral corruption.
entries.usage_notes: Viewed as a locus of Israelite dispersion and captivity in the modern era, including shipment by sea per covenant curses.

entries.definition: Modern superpower regarded as the eighth head of the Red Dragon — inheritor of Greco-Roman and British dominion.
entries.usage_notes: America continues the Edomite system through political, military, and cultural control. Identified in prophetic interpretation as Babylon the Great, it unites the horns’ power and enforces global influence. The transatlantic slave trade fulfilled covenant curses, bringing Israelites to a new Egypt by ships.

entries.definition: People east of the Jordan, descendants of Lot; frequent rivals of Israel.
A prominent Canaanite people often listed among those displaced by Israel in the conquest narratives.
Spiritual messengers or agents of YHWH who perform His will among men and nations.
entries.usage_notes: From Hebrew 'malʾāk' meaning messenger or envoy. Angels deliver revelation (Genesis 18:2; Daniel 9:21), provide protection (Psalm 91:11), and execute divine judgment (2 Samuel 24:16). They are not objects of worship but servants acting by command of YHWH.

entries.definition: Desert-dwelling peoples east and south of Israel; appear in trade, migration, and prophecy contexts.
Descendants of Ishmael and Abraham through Hagar; inhabit Arabian regions and appear throughout Scripture.
One of the chief princes among the heavenly host; defender of Israel in spiritual conflict.
entries.usage_notes: Scripture names only Michael (Hebrew: Mikha’el, 'Who is like God?') as a leading messenger and protector of Israel (Daniel 10:13, 12:1). He stands against opposing angelic powers governing nations. The term 'archangel' denotes preeminence, not divinity.

entries.definition: Descendant of Gomer (Table of Nations). Project stance: marker for northern peoples later associated with European domains.
Common mount and draft animal; associated with humility and messianic entry.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Canaanite, Egyptian, and Nubian agrarian systems; ubiquitous village transport.

entries.definition: Powerful Near Eastern empire that conquered northern Israel and exiled its inhabitants.
Second beast in Daniel’s vision; represents Medo-Persia’s dual empire.
entries.usage_notes: Raised on one side, symbolizing imbalance; three ribs suggest conquests of Lydia, Babylon, and Egypt.

entries.definition: Generic prophetic symbol for empires or kingdoms rising in succession to rule the earth.
entries.usage_notes: Used in Daniel and Revelation to denote political powers; rooted in ancient Near Eastern animal iconography.

entries.definition: Gigantic land creature paired with Leviathan; symbol of terrestrial empires rooted in the earth’s strength.
entries.usage_notes: Represents grounded, land-based powers that boast against heaven. God’s sovereignty over Behemoth emphasizes the futility of human and national pride.

entries.definition: Indigenous North African peoples linked by tradition to ancient Hamitic and Israelite dispersions.
Town in Judah identified as the birthplace of David and of Jesus the Messiah.
Figurative and literal description of Israelite skin tone in texts such as Song of Solomon 1:5 and Lamentations 5:10.
Principal Edomite city; appears in prophetic judgments; key to Edomite geography in project mapping.
Maritime empire descending from the Roman and Edomite line; exercised dominion across the seas and colonies.
entries.usage_notes: Britain represents the western branch of Edom’s dominion, fulfilling prophecies of the nations ruling from the isles. Its colonization of the Americas and Africa extended the Dragon’s power globally under the banner of Christian imperialism and commerce.

entries.definition: Bronze-like brown/radiant tone used in visionary descriptions.
Polished bronze mirror; women donated such mirrors for the Tabernacle’s laver.
Common descriptive tone among Near Eastern populations; symbolic of Adamic origin (from the soil).
Polished, gleaming bronze-like brown; biblical theophanic/angelic imagery.
Beast of burden vital to desert caravans; image of endurance and wealth.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Arabian and Saharan belts; integral to Abrahamic, Midianite, and Nabataean trade.

entries.definition: Inhabitants of the land later promised to Abraham and his seed; composed of related peoples such as Hittites, Amorites, and Jebusites.
Lakeside town on the Sea of Galilee serving as a base for Jesus’ ministry.
State of bondage or exile among foreign nations.
entries.usage_notes: Used for ancient Assyrian/Babylonian exiles and for modern transatlantic captivity.

entries.definition: Mesopotamian people who rose to power under Nebuchadnezzar; responsible for Judah’s exile.
Winged beings guarding sacred space and attending the throne of YHWH.
entries.usage_notes: Appearing first at Eden’s east gate (Genesis 3:24), later woven into the tabernacle and placed over the Ark of the Covenant (Exodus 25:18–22). They represent divine guardianship, mobility, and the intersection of heaven and earth.

entries.definition: Animals permitted for Israelite consumption and sacrifice under Torah law.
entries.usage_notes: Include land animals with split hooves and that chew cud, sea creatures with fins and scales, certain birds and insects.

entries.definition: Visible masses of condensed vapor in the atmosphere; carriers of water and divine imagery.
entries.usage_notes: In meteorology, clouds form when warm air cools and condenses. Biblically, clouds accompany divine presence and glory—YHWH rides upon them and Christ returns with them. They veil and reveal simultaneously.

entries.definition: Foreign domination through conquest and settlement, often justified by religious or racial ideology.
entries.usage_notes: Parallels biblical imperialism such as Babylon and Rome in exploitation of resources and peoples.

entries.definition: Concept expressing variation in hue among Adamic peoples; does not imply racial hierarchy in Scripture.
Visible surface tone of the skin, connected to soil and divine creation motif (Adam from red-brown earth).
Reddish-brown like polished copper; allied to ‘burnished bronze’ imagery.
Egyptian Christians preserving ancient Egyptian lineage and liturgical language; descendants of Mizraim.
Small engraved stone rolled on clay to leave an impression; part of wider Near Eastern sealing culture paralleling biblical ‘seals’.
Major Aramean city to Israel’s northeast; notable in prophetic oracles and Paul’s conversion.
Dispersion of Israelite peoples across foreign lands.
entries.usage_notes: Modern diaspora connects African-descended Israelites to biblical exiles.

entries.definition: Symbol of peace and purity; used in offerings; Noah’s sign of mercy.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Levant, Nile Delta, and sub-Saharan flyways and groves.

entries.definition: Fourth and final beast in Daniel’s vision; symbolizes Rome’s brutal and iron rule.
entries.usage_notes: Teeth of iron and ten horns mark power and fragmentation; parallels Revelation beast imagery.

entries.definition: Archaic English term for dark, dull brown; natural Near Eastern hue.
Earthy hue linked to Adamic origin from dust/soil.
Raptor emblematic of divine protection and renewal.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Sinai heights, Arabian escarpments, Kushite ranges.

entries.definition: The terrestrial creation formed by YHWH as the habitation of mankind and the stage of covenant history.
entries.usage_notes: Biblically, the earth is described as established and immovable (Psalm 104:5) yet dynamically governed by divine laws of motion and gravity. It is the third planet from the sun, revolving once every 24 hours on its axis and orbiting the sun every 365 days. Prophetic language presents the earth as both literal dwelling and symbolic realm of kingdoms and peoples under heaven’s authority.

entries.definition: Of clay/earth; figurative of human vessel and origin.
Deep brown-to-black coloration; later poetic term denoting dignity and beauty.
Nation descended from Esau; located south of Judah in Mount Seir and later called Idumea under Greek and Roman dominion.
entries.usage_notes: Edom’s hostility toward Israel became a central prophetic theme. Scripture foretells its final desolation (Obadiah 1; Isaiah 34). Historically, the Idumeans were absorbed into Judea under John Hyrcanus and produced the Herodian dynasty under Rome, continuing Edomite influence into the imperial and European world.

entries.definition: Historical and prophetic tracing of Esau’s descendants from ancient Edom through Rome, Europe, and America.
entries.usage_notes: The Edomite lineage never vanished but transformed through successive empires. Esau’s dominion prophecy (Genesis 27:39–40) unfolds as Edom rules by the sword through Rome, the European powers, and America. Modern institutions of finance, war, and culture reflect Edom’s ongoing presence and opposition to Israel’s restoration.

entries.definition: Relatives of Israel through Esau; occupied the territory south of Judah.
Ancient Hamitic people of the Nile valley; closely tied to early Israelite sojourn and deliverance.
Descendants of Mizraim, son of Ham; ancient people of the Nile Valley with deep ties to Israelite history.
Firstborn son of Isaac and twin brother of Jacob (Israel); progenitor of the nation of Edom.
entries.usage_notes: Esau is described as 'red' and 'hairy' (Genesis 25:25), symbolizing his earthly nature and covenant divergence. He sold his birthright, leading to the prophetic separation of Jacob and Esau’s destinies. His descendants settled in Mount Seir and became the Edomites, later intertwined with Idumeans under Greco-Roman rule.

entries.definition: People of Kush (south of Egypt), frequently referenced in biblical and classical sources for military strength and alliance with Israel.
Biblical Cushite peoples south of Egypt; known for their dark complexion and royal interactions with Israel.
Collective body of nations emerging from Rome’s fragmentation; identified as the ten horns of the Dragon and Beast in Revelation.
entries.usage_notes: The European confederation extends Edom’s geopolitical dominion through successive empires and alliances. Nations such as France, Spain, Germany, and Britain reflect the prophetic horns, bound by shared Roman-Edomite heritage and anti-Israelite governance throughout history.

entries.definition: In biblical idiom: beautiful/well-formed, not a statement of paleness.
The expanse dividing the waters above from the waters below; the visible sky and the spiritual heavens beyond.
entries.usage_notes: Scientifically, the firmament encompasses Earth’s atmosphere and outer space; biblically, it represents the ordered structure sustaining life and separating domains. It manifests God’s craftsmanship (Psalm 19:1) and serves as the stage of celestial order, prophecy, and divine throne imagery.

entries.definition: Northern district of Israel, associated with mixed populations and the early ministry of Jesus.
Northern district associated with mixed populations including Israelites and non-israelites; used to frame the setting of Jesus’s early ministry.
entries.usage_notes: Indicates a border/mixed region rather than a fixed ethnic label. There are New-Testament references corresponding to these deductions

entries.etymology: Lat. gentilis ‘of a gens’; in Scripture aligns with Heb. goy/goyim and Gk. ethnos/ethnē.
entries.definition: Term used of both Israelites and non-Israelites depending on context: ‘nation/people’ broadly; sometimes Israel herself; sometimes other nations.
entries.usage_notes: Singular of ‘Gentiles’. Context-driven: can mean a non-Israelite, or generically a member of ‘a nation’; Israel herself is called a nation (goy/ethnos) in multiple passages.

entries.etymology: Via Latin gentilis ‘of a gens’; in Scripture maps to Heb. goy/goyim, Gk. ethnos/ethnē.
entries.definition: Context-dependent term for ‘nations/peoples’; sometimes used of Israel as a nation, sometimes of non-Israelite nations.
entries.usage_notes: Term for ‘nations/peoples’. In Scripture Israel herself is called a goy/ethnos (a nation): e.g., Gen 12:2; Exod 19:6; Luke 7:5; John 11:51–52; 1 Pet 2:9; cf. Rom 9:24–26.

entries.definition: One of the listed Canaanite peoples in the land promised to Israel.
Hardy caprine used for milk, meat, skins, and ritual; central to Day of Atonement.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Judean highlands and Arabian ranges; well-adapted to arid escarpments.

entries.definition: Greek-speaking peoples of the Mediterranean; a common NT contrast-category with ‘Jews’.

entries.etymology: Perhaps ‘hot’; name of Noah’s youngest son.
entries.definition: Youngest son of Noah; born before the Flood and among the eight survivors. Progenitor associated with Egyptians, Kushites/Ethiopians, Libyans, and Canaanites (Afro-Hamitic groups, distinct from Negro Israelites in this project stance).
entries.usage_notes: Project stance: Ham’s lines are African (Egypt, Kush/Ethiopia, Put/Libya, Canaan) and are not identified as the Negro Israelite line; genealogical tables in Gen 10 frame these peoples.

entries.definition: Represents Greece and Alexander the Great’s rapid conquest in Daniel’s prophecy.
entries.usage_notes: The notable horn symbolizes Alexander; four horns his successors after his death.

entries.definition: Scripture’s layered view of heaven as sky, cosmos, and divine dwelling.
entries.usage_notes: Scientifically aligns with Earth’s atmosphere, outer space, and spiritual dimension beyond the physical. Paul refers to the 'third heaven' as the dwelling of God (2 Corinthians 12:2). This threefold design mirrors temple structure—outer court, holy place, and most holy place.

entries.definition: Ancient ethnonym applied to Israelites, especially in early or foreign contexts. Refers to Abraham and his descendants before national designation as Israel.
Ancient city in the hill country of Judah; linked to Abraham and David’s early reign.
Dynastic ruler of Judea under Roman authority; descendant of Edom through the Idumeans.
entries.usage_notes: Herod the Great (37–4 BCE) was of Edomite lineage forcibly converted to Judaism. His reign fulfilled the prophecy of Esau’s dominion over Jacob and exemplified Edomite rule over Israel during the Gentile era. His descendants continued to govern under Rome.

entries.definition: Political group aligned with Herod’s line; project stance: illustrative of Idumean ascendancy under Rome.
An Anatolian and Canaanite people frequently noted in Scripture; Abraham purchased land from them for Sarah’s burial.
Canaanite subgroup dwelling among the hill country and key towns in Israel’s land.
A descriptive element of complexion; used poetically for the diversity within Shemitic and Hamitic peoples.
Later name/form of Edom and its people; associated with Herodian-era Judea and, in project stance, linked downstream to European dominions.
Son of Abraham and Sarah; covenant heir and father of Jacob and Esau.
Descendants of Ishmael; caravan traders appearing in Israel’s narratives.
Decorative ivory work found in Israelite palatial contexts; associated with luxury and foreign trade.
Son of Isaac; renamed Israel; eponymous father of the twelve tribes.
Canaanite people dwelling in Jerusalem (Jebus) before David captured the city.
Capital city of Israel/Judah; site of the Temple and focal point of worship and pilgrimage.
Southern province/region centered on Jerusalem in Second Temple times; heartland of the Judeans.
Israelite ethnonym linked to Judah/Judea; sometimes denotes members/partisans of the Judean polity.
entries.usage_notes: In Second Temple usage, political/cultural sense can appear alongside lineage. This term is exclusively applied to descendants of Judah only, but later became ascribed to the South Kingdom when speaking generally

entries.definition: Divine standard of righteousness and equity; basis for deliverance from oppression.
entries.usage_notes: Prophets equated justice with covenant faithfulness; restoration hinges on it.

entries.definition: Nomadic clan allied with Israel at points; associated with Moses’ in-laws.
Term for isles/coastal peoples (Cyprus/Greco-Roman). Project stance: vector connecting Mediterranean powers to later Edomite dominion.
Israelites interlinked with Cushite lines through intermarriage and migration; reflected in Moses’ Cushite wife.
Peoples south of Egypt (Nubia/Kush) known from biblical and classical sources; frequently interact with Egypt and Israel.
entries.usage_notes: ‘Ethiopian’ in Greek sources can be broad; usage varies by author and era. For example, historians were not able to distinguish Coptics, Israelites, and Nubians from one another

entries.definition: African people south of Egypt (Nubia/Kush), noted in both biblical and classical sources.
Young sheep central to sacrificial life in Israel; emblem of innocence and substitution.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Levantine hill-country and NE African pastoral zones herded by Semitic nomads. Symbol of atonement and the Messiah.

entries.definition: Third beast in Daniel’s vision; symbolizes swift Grecian conquest under Alexander the Great.
entries.usage_notes: Four wings and four heads indicate rapid expansion and division of empire.

entries.definition: Ancient peoples of the Levant, including Israelites, Canaanites, and Phoenicians.
Mythic sea creature representing chaos, empire, and nations rising from the waters of the Gentiles.
entries.usage_notes: Symbolic of proud, sea-based kingdoms that oppose YHWH’s order; associated with Egypt and later maritime empires. Its defeat foreshadows the fall of the nations before Israel’s restoration.

entries.definition: Descendants of Put, son of Ham; North African people west of Egypt known to Scripture and classical sources.
Dual creation elements symbolizing knowledge and ignorance, righteousness and sin.
entries.usage_notes: Scientifically manifest in the alternation of day and night through Earth’s rotation. Spiritually, light represents divine truth and life; darkness represents deception and death. Prophets and apostles employ this dualism to describe moral and cosmic conflict.

entries.definition: Large predator once native to the Levant and NE Africa; image of power and kingship.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Canaan/Judea, Rift Valley, and Ethiopian ranges prior to regional extirpation. Title 'Lion of Judah'.

entries.definition: First beast in Daniel’s vision; symbolizing Babylon’s majesty and dominance.
entries.usage_notes: Seen with eagle’s wings; imagery tied to Babylonian iconography from Mesopotamia.

entries.definition: Prophetic figure emerging from beast imagery in Daniel and Revelation; signifies a blasphemous power opposing the saints.
entries.usage_notes: Arises among ten horns of the final beast; interpreted variously across Israelite and apocalyptic traditions.

entries.definition: A people of northwestern Iran who, with the Persians, overthrew Assyria and later ruled jointly as the Medo-Persian power.
Possessing natural melanin-based pigmentation; descriptive of original Adamic and Shemitic peoples.
The natural pigment determining complexion and protection from solar radiation; biblically aligned with the 'burnished' or 'ruddy brown' hues of Semitic peoples.
Nomadic desert people related to Abraham through Keturah; Moses sojourned in Midian.
Ninth-century BCE basalt stela of King Mesha; extrabiblical witness to Israel–Moab conflict described in Scripture.
People east of the Dead Sea, descended from Lot; frequent neighbors and rivals of Israel.
The lesser light created to govern the night and mark appointed times (moedim) within the Israelite calendar.
entries.usage_notes: Astronomically, the moon is Earth’s natural satellite reflecting sunlight, with a synodic cycle of 29.5 days. Biblically, it determines feasts, months, and seasons (Psalm 104:19). Prophetically, the moon symbolizes reflection, renewal, and the faithful witness of Israel amid darkness.

entries.etymology: Lat. Maurus; Gk. mauros ‘dark/dusky’; later ethnonym for North-West African peoples in classical/medieval usage.
entries.definition: Historical term for Black peoples of North-West Africa; in some traditions, used for Black Hebrews or Africans in diaspora contexts.
entries.usage_notes: Project stance: ‘Moor’ can denote Black Hebrews/Africans in later sources; biblically proximate references use ‘Ethiopian/Kushite’, not ‘Moor’, but are relevant for complexion and African identity.

entries.definition: Prophet and lawgiver who leads Israel from Egypt and mediates the covenant.
Homeland of Esau/Edom; prophetically addressed as seat of enduring hostility to Israel; foundation node in Edomite identity.
Arabian and Edomite-linked people dwelling east of the Jordan; traders known for Petra.
Village in Galilee associated with Jesus’ upbringing and identity as a Nazarene.

A term used historically to describe the dark-skinned descendants of Shem and Ham; linguistically and ethnically linked to 'Niger,' which means black; often misapplied by European scholars but is here restored to its Israelite origin. For example Simeon and Barnabas Niger.
Assyrian imperial city addressed by Jonah and later condemned in Nahum.
Systematic exploitation or affliction of a people by political or social power.
entries.usage_notes: Frequently condemned by prophets; tied to divine judgment on nations.

entries.definition: Ink-inscribed potsherd used for everyday notes and correspondence; famous Hebrew examples include the Lachish Letters.
Domesticated bovine for plowing and sacrifice; emblem of covenant labor and strength.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Bred across Egypt, Mesopotamia, and Shemite pastoral lands; staple of agrarian economy.

entries.definition: Writing material from Nile reeds; reflects Egyptian and early Israelite textual transmission contexts.
Eastern people under Parthian rule; present in Jerusalem at Pentecost.
Indigenous people groups in Canaan frequently listed among Israel’s neighbors.
Empire that succeeded Babylon and allowed the Israelites to return to their land under Cyrus the Great.
Seafaring group on the southwest coast of Canaan; recurring adversaries of Israel.
Seafaring Canaanite peoples inhabiting Tyre and Sidon; skilled in trade and craftsmanship.
Biological term (melanin); spiritual metaphor for vitality and divine formation of man from dust.
Ideological hierarchy based on perceived physical traits or race, emerging in the modern colonial period.
entries.usage_notes: Absent in Scripture, which categorizes humanity by lineage and covenant, not color; modern racism undergirded colonial and transatlantic oppression.

entries.definition: Condensed moisture descending from the atmosphere to nourish the earth.
entries.usage_notes: Scientifically part of the water cycle through evaporation and condensation. Biblically, rain and dew symbolize divine favor, doctrine, and restoration (Deuteronomy 32:2). Their withholding represents judgment and drought of truth.

entries.definition: Optical arc formed by refraction and dispersion of light through water droplets; instituted as a divine covenant sign after the Flood.
entries.usage_notes: Scientifically demonstrates light’s color spectrum. Biblically, the rainbow symbolizes YHWH’s mercy and restraint from global destruction. Prophetically, it reappears around the throne in Revelation, affirming continuity of covenant and creation.

entries.definition: Male sheep; archetype of substitutionary sacrifice in Abraham’s test.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Upper Nile, Arabia, and Canaanite hill-country flocks.

entries.definition: Symbol in Daniel 8 representing the Medo-Persian empire.
entries.usage_notes: Two horns indicate the dual kingdom; aligned with prophetic imagery of Persia’s rise.

entries.definition: Apocalyptic symbol of the great adversary in Revelation, described as having seven heads and ten horns. The color red parallels Edom (Esau), whose descendants formed the ruling empires of the Gentile age.
entries.usage_notes: The seven heads represent the major Edomite-influenced imperial powers: Greece, Rome, Spain, France, Germany, Russia, and Great Britain — with the eighth head, America, arising as their final extension. The ten horns signify the confederated European nations (Belgium, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Germany, United Kingdom, Italy, Greece, France, Denmark, and Ireland) forming the dragon’s geopolitical structure. In prophetic typology, the Red Dragon empowers the Beast and persecutes the remnant of Israel.

entries.definition: Act of deliverance or buying back from bondage.
entries.usage_notes: Core to Israelite identity, including physical, social, and spiritual freedom.

entries.definition: Imperial power governing Judea in the Second Temple period of the New Testament.
Imperial power over Judea. Project stance: associates Rome with Edom/Idumea in later Israelite/Jewish readings and polemics.
Imperial system that succeeded Greece and absorbed Idumean influence through political and religious syncretism.
entries.usage_notes: Rome embodied the Edomite spirit of dominion and opposition to Israel, continuing the line of Esau through conquest and governance. The Herodian dynasty linked Edom directly to Rome, merging Idumean blood with imperial authority. Prophetic literature equates Rome with the iron kingdom that crushed and ruled the earth.

entries.definition: Term used of youthful appearance or brown, earthy complexion; contrasted with the deeper/darker hue common among Hebrews.
entries.usage_notes: Project stance: ‘ruddy’ signals a warm-brown/earthy tone or youthful glow, not a pale or non-brown phenotype; compare narrative contrasts in David’s description.

entries.definition: Descriptive term for an earthy, brown tone (from Heb. admoni); misinterpreted in modern English as 'red.'
Hill-country region and former northern capital; later a distinct community neighboring Judea.
Population of northern Israel after Assyrian exile; retained parts of Israelite law and worship.
Prophetic beast that carries the Harlot Babylon in Revelation; scarlet color denotes sin, blood, and royal deceit.
entries.usage_notes: Embodies the global imperial system empowered by the Red Dragon. The scarlet hue parallels Edom’s redness and Babylon’s luxury and guilt; represents the confederation of nations under the final world order.

entries.definition: Divinely ordained cycles of time established by the movements of the sun and moon.
entries.usage_notes: Scientifically, seasons arise from Earth’s axial tilt and orbit around the sun; biblically, the same cycles govern Israel’s moedim—Sabbaths, feasts, and jubilees (Genesis 1:14). These appointed times reveal prophetic patterns tied to agricultural and redemptive seasons.

entries.definition: Fiery beings surrounding the throne of YHWH, proclaiming His holiness.
entries.usage_notes: From Hebrew 'śārāph' meaning to burn. Described in Isaiah’s vision as six-winged beings crying 'Holy, holy, holy' (Isaiah 6:1–7). Their fire symbolizes purity and the consuming nature of divine presence.

entries.definition: Snake; emblem of cunning and judgment yet also healing when lifted up.
entries.usage_notes: Habitat (ancient): Nile corridor, Arabian and Levantine deserts, oases, and wadis.

entries.definition: Ancient deceiver and enemy of the covenant people, appearing from Eden to Revelation as the personification of deceit and rebellion.
entries.usage_notes: The serpent is the root symbol later embodied in the Red Dragon; represents satanic craft, false religion, and corruption of divine truth among nations.

entries.definition: Temporary labor or debt bondage; common in Israelite law as a restorative measure rather than perpetual enslavement.
entries.usage_notes: Differentiated from slavery by duration and humane conditions; often a path to freedom or restitution.

entries.definition: Standard weight/monetary measure used in valuations and trade in Israel.
Descendants of Shem, one of Noah’s sons; line includes the Hebrews, Assyrians, and Aramaeans.
Seal ring symbolizing delegated authority; used to authenticate decrees and transfers of power.
Celestial phenomena appointed as omens or messages in biblical prophecy.
entries.usage_notes: Astronomically includes eclipses, comets, and planetary alignments. Biblically, these events accompany major transitions or judgments (Joel 2:30–31). Christ foretold signs in the sun, moon, and stars preceding His return (Luke 21:25–27).

entries.definition: System of human bondage practiced in various forms; the transatlantic variant displaced millions of Israelite descendants to the Americas.
entries.usage_notes: Distinguished from servitude under Mosaic law, which involved restitution and humane treatment; modern chattel slavery was racialized and violated covenant principles.

entries.definition: Celestial bodies that emit or reflect light; created for signs, seasons, and navigation.
entries.usage_notes: Modern astronomy identifies stars as luminous spheres of plasma held by gravity. In Scripture, stars symbolize both physical lights and spiritual beings (angels) or rulers (Genesis 15:5, Revelation 1:20). Their mathematical precision demonstrates divine order, and their prophetic falling often signals political or angelic downfall.

entries.definition: Inscribed stone monument recording covenants, boundaries, or victories (e.g., memorial stones set up in Israel and neighboring lands).
Southern Nile peoples identified with biblical Kush; strong interaction with Egypt and Israel.
The greater light created on the fourth day to rule the day and sustain life through light and energy.
entries.usage_notes: Scientifically, the sun is a G-type main-sequence star at the center of the solar system, converting hydrogen to helium through nuclear fusion. Biblically, it symbolizes righteousness, divine order, and the radiance of the Messiah (Malachi 4:2). The sun’s predictable cycles uphold appointed times, agricultural rhythms, and prophetic imagery of judgment and glory.

entries.definition: Edomite district famous for ‘wisdom’; used by prophets as emblem of Edom’s strength to be judged.
Atmospheric discharge and sound resulting from electrical energy; symbolic of divine power and voice.
entries.usage_notes: Scientifically caused by rapid heating of air during lightning strikes. In Scripture, thunder and lightning accompany theophanies, signifying divine speech, judgment, and awe (Exodus 19:16). Prophetic literature equates them with the power of God’s voice and angelic manifestation.

entries.definition: Earth-pigment name signifying reddish-brown (ruddy) tone.
Animals forbidden for Israelite diet and sacrifice according to Levitical law.
entries.usage_notes: Include swine, shellfish, raptors, and animals lacking split hooves or cud-chewing; symbolic of separation and holiness.

entries.definition: Priestly lots kept in the breastplate of judgment for inquiry of YHWH on national matters.
Biblical description of the divided waters during creation; representing atmospheric and terrestrial domains.
entries.usage_notes: Physically corresponds to Earth’s hydrological balance—vapor, clouds, and oceans. Spiritually symbolizes separation between heavenly and earthly realms. Prophets employ the motif to signify divine order and blessing.

entries.definition: Hebrew term 'ruach' meaning breath, wind, or spirit; the invisible force of life and motion.
entries.usage_notes: In physics, wind arises from atmospheric pressure differences; in Scripture, Ruach denotes both natural air and divine Spirit animating creation. It symbolizes vitality, inspiration, and divine movement upon the waters (Genesis 1:2).
